zuul/executor/server.py.message: If we are going to call _restoreRepoState() outside of a merger context we should consider making it a public method.

This list is disjoint from the new merge_items list above. I think that means we were calling setRepoState() below on at least a subset of of the repos we are calling _restoreRepoState() against above. This has me confused as to how this change is helpful since setRepoState() calls _restoreRepoState() (see below).

This is the existing public method in the merger which calls merger._restoreRepoState(). This is what has me confused about the assertion that we should be using _restoreRepoState() for the fix of this problem. The general process previously seemed to be:

  * Update all repos if necessary
  * Merge changes
  * Update repo to reflect merges using setRepoState

Within that process addressing stale refs in the first step across all repos seems to avoid needing to use merger internals. It also seems simpler to understand (though none of this is terribly simple).

zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py.message: If _dispatchEventsMain() raises an exception we probably want to cancel/remove futures in _event_forward_queue so we don't try to ack those later, as they might haven been processed by a different scheduler in the meantime.

Is self.event_queue stored in zk? If not then I think we would drop any events that have arrived to this scheduler without sending them off for preprocessing. If This scheduler is stopped to force another to take over we would experience in a gap in events.

It is stored in ZK!  So the idea is that we can stop here at any time, and even though this returned an event, it's still in ZK and unack'd.  So the next processor can take over.

We're responsible for finishing processing any events we previously handled, which is why the method above continues running the second half of the process even after we've stopped the first (to drain our second queue).

Only when everything is drained do we exit.  If it takes a while to drain the second half of our queue, we may pause processing for a while, but we won't lose events.

I marked the initializer of self.event_queue below.
Oh, I should add if we're forcibly terminated, obviously we can't drain our second queue, but in that case the original events are still un-ack'd, so again, they'll be processed by the next owner.
I believe this is the first event queue.

doc/source/admin/cpu-models.rst.message:
One of the benefits of 'host-model' is that it doesn't *need* to be identical, and libvirt will do the right thing to calculate live migration compatibility.

We should also work in the below important points about 'host-model'.  They answer the common question of "What exactly are the advantages of 'host-model'?"  I've mentioned these elsewhere[1][2] in the past, but having them written down is useful.  

- It provides maximum possible CPU features from the host to the guest
- It auto-adds critical guest CPU flags — e.g. ``spec-ctrl`` and others for mitigation from certain security flaws — *provided* the CPU microcode, kernel, QEMU, and libvirt are all updated
- It computes live migration compatibility, with the caveat of live migration in both directions is not possible.  (See below.)


`host-model` and live migration
-------------------------------

When using libvirt's 'host-model', live migration in both directions is not always guaranteed, because of the following:

During live migration, the source CPU model definition is transferred to the destination host as-is.  This results in the migrated guest on the destination seeing exactly the same CPU model as on source — *even if* the destination compute host is capable of providing more CPU features.  However, shutting down and restarting the guest on the may present different hardware to the guest, as per the new capabilities of the destination compute.


[1] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/Effective-Virtual-CPU-Configuration-in-Nova-Berlin2018.pdf
[2] https://kashyapc.fedorapeople.org/Secure-CPU-config-for-KVM-based-guests-RHT_TechDay_Brussels_2020.pdf

I suggest to be more explicit about live migration with 'host-passthrough', as there can be mysterious failures in this scenario:

For live migration with 'host-passthrough' to work, along with *identical* physical CPUs on source and destination hosts, you also must have along with identical kernel _and_ CPU microcode versions.

(The reason for even matching CPU microcode version is that hardware performance counters are exposed to an instance, it is likely that they may vary between different CPU models.  There may be other reasons due to security fixes for some hardware security flaws being included in CPU microcode.)

The below two bullet points convey the point sufficient enough to me.  So I don't insist.

it seems this is not rendered properly. http://storage.bhs.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_d4d/781438/2/check/openstack-tox-docs/d4d9f30/docs/admin/cpu-models.html#cpu-modes

releasenotes/notes/rbd-encryption-known-.message:
I wonder if this should say "created from a non-encrypted volume uploaded as an image, or an image that has a size exactly on a gigabyte boundary" or so.

(Which is the reason for the first scenario, cinder volumes being multiples of GBs.)
I would shy away from specifying a size like this...
I think the problem is that it's attachable but is missing the end of the data, because the volume was truncated?

I was going by the bug report [0], but I agree with your analysis that the header will be written fine, the resize will truncate data at the other end of the ceph image.

[0] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1922408

As we discussed this might also be the case with nfs since IIRC both drivers use almost the same code for image encryption. Although I'm not entirely sure it's the same case with nfs also but if it is then we should also mention nfs here.
I'll check with Eric and Sofia about the NFS situation.  Maybe this should be a general encrypted volume issues note, and I can refer to that doc change Sofia made in victoria (change I3fd514126dbd).
I wasn't able to work on the NFS yet and considering that encryption isn't fully supported yet I think we could keep it Ceph only for now.
Ignore my comment, this is correct.

Yes, as Brian said the size returned after rbd self._clone seems to be correct[1], the problem is that cinder forces to truncate the size of the volume after that. This happens because when using encryption cinder is not considering the size of the encryption header.

Currently, cinder lets you create a volume from a diff volume type than the source volume - even specifying an snapshot-id-. So I think It doesn't matter if the source volume is encrypted or not. 

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py#L1050

Thanks for checking, I was confused too.  From the bug report, it sounds like for RBD, we have the behavior we want, i.e., the encrypted volume's actual size is volume.size + header (hence, volume.size worth of user-usable space), and the problem is that the driver resizes a volume created from that snapshot to volume.size and can possibly truncate some data.  But I have not actually verified this behavior.

It turns out that a cleaning step should never call task.process_event('fail'). If the cleaning step fails in this manner, then the node won't be put into maintenance mode, which it should be, and stale state will be left in node.driver_internal_info. The end result of this is that if you put the node back into manage after the failure and try to rerun the cleaning step, it will never be kicked off. Also, in the code above, node.last_error will be discarded because there is no node.save() call after it.

While I know you didn't write this code, I hate to see us touch fundamentally broken code and not fix it.

Please replace the 2 lines above with a call to conductor.utils.cleaning_error_handler(task, error_message)

This will put the node into maintenance mode, clear the state on the node which fixes the hanging cleaning step bug, and it calls node.save(), which will result in last_error being updated on the node.

When testing, be sure to do an "openstack node show" and verify that last_error actually contains the error message.

ironic/drivers/modules/drac/bios.py.message: Below I note about the use of a timezone aware time. It might be a bad idea since your using it as a comparison to track the passage of time, and this can easily break if we ever change the conductor to be multi-process on host or multi-conductor pooled activities using locks for coordination. Timezones are administratively set on machines and unfortunately in cases where it was not done automatically via management tooling, very often it gets set incorrectly or inconsistently by humans as it is set to their relative context.
using UTC time without timezone which is required for date arithmetic and also using UTC time for all time related operation as it does not change with timezone.

ironic/drivers/modules/drac/bios.py.message: Generally you always want to avoid storing or using a time zone. Especially if conductors are not configured for the same local time zone, or are spread across the world.  It is better to take the approach of "what time is it right now in UTC" and local time with a timezone does not matter.

this could be alternative remove timezone after parse_isotime , as to parse_isotime returns with tzinfo , please suggest 

timeutils.utcnow()-timeutils.parse_isotime(str(factory_reset_time)).replace(tzinfo=None)

it is UTC as it is right now. It is not local time. Here are differences with param and without, the only difference is TZ field, time is the same, and that corresponds to UTC as of this writing.

  >>> timeutils.utcnow(with_timezone=True)
  datetime.datetime(2021, 1, 25, 15, 44, 57, 120315, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)
  >>> timeutils.utcnow()
  datetime.datetime(2021, 1, 25, 15, 45, 2, 743347)

This is necessary because `parse_isotime` is adding TZ info even if not explicitly providing. Alternative solution would be to remove TZ info as Yogesh has suggested above. I don't see option in oslo_utils.parse_isotime not to add TZ info.

  >>> timeutils.parse_isotime(str(timeutils.utcnow()))
  datetime.datetime(2021, 1, 25, 15, 47, 56, 308320, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)

When time diff is calculated this is what happens without TZ:

  >>> timeutils.utcnow() - timeutils.parse_isotime(str(timeutils.utcnow()))
  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  TypeError: can't subtract offset-naive and offset-aware datetimes

This works when TZ added:

  >>> timeutils.utcnow(with_timezone=True) - timeutils.parse_isotime(str(timeutils.utcnow()))
  datetime.timedelta(days=-1, seconds=86399, microseconds=999993)


Are you suggesting that instead of explicitly adding that it is really UTC, should go alternative approach as suggested by Yogesh? Or are there any other suggestions?
I think that it's clearer as it is, rather then doing `tzinfo=None`.

my examples were not entirely precise to depict actual code being used in Ironic - time zone is added to the source value when used for parse_isotime. It is being set in line 438. It will be UTC even if somebody deletes with_timezone=True there, because that's what the function does - it is named utcnow after all and this little flag controls whether TZ=UTC field is added or not.

I still think this is fine as it is. The conflict happens because `utcnow` by default does not add TZ field, but parse_isotime adds TZ field even if it's missing in source. And subtraction rejects calculation because having default settings one value is with TZ, another is not. What this code does is it makes sure that both values will have TZ and it will be UTC for both.

To be more precise an example should have been like this: 

  timeutils.utcnow(with_timezone=True) - timeutils.parse_isotime(str(timeutils.utcnow(with_timezone=True)))

By default if ignoring existence of with_timezone

  >>> timeutils.utcnow() - timeutils.parse_isotime(str(timeutils.utcnow()))
  Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  TypeError: can't subtract offset-naive and offset-aware datetimes


This calculation is not touching the time coming from BMC, that's different value and being handled in line 231 where it checks if time has changed and that's it.

This block is comparing value set in line 438 (then stored in internal info) and moment it runs.
This block checks if timeout has occurred since reboot started to avoid lingering too long if something goes wrong. Both values come from conductor running the code.

I don't see value in converting UTC in seconds and storing on node or converting back and forth, this is already UTC and in current format it is more readable in case human needs to take a look at internal info when debugging, etc. On node this will be stored like '2021-02-01 16:09:27.591516+00:00'
this will add tzinfo to UTC (not server's local), so it will be fine. And as parse_isotime below returns with tzinfo (UTC), then it can't use time with and without timezone to calculate.

## How to run your script as airshipctl phase -  I think that this is what reader would actually want to see

1) Create a phase document (kind: Phase)
2) Create executor document (kind: GenericContainer)

3) Add your script as a ConfigMap
a) add kustomize resources
b) include them into PhaseConfigBundle

4) Make sure it is added to the bundle:
a) airshipctl phase render --source config -k ConfigMap
find your configmap in the output
b) airshipctl phase render --source config -k Phase
find your phase in output
c) airshipctl phase render --source config -k GenericContainer
find your executor in output

5) run your phase:
airshipctl phase run get-node-phase

zuul/driver/gerrit/gerritconnection.py.message:
This gets called when zk_client.disconnect() is called, which seems like in practice will only happen when the scheduler is shutting down.  In that case, _stopped should already be set.  Unless I'm missing something, I'm not sure this change adds anything.

Based on the commit message, are we looking for something where if the zk connection is broken, we exit the loop so that we can try to win the election again?  (see below)
I somehow expected the on disconnect listeners to also get called when the connection is lost. So yes, that doesn't work as intended. I'll add a hook to listen for connection losses.

There is a .lost attribute of the ZooKeeperClient class, but I think we do need the event-based system you have here, because our poll timeout is large -- it's possible we could lose the connection, another client could win the election and start reporting events, and then our connection could be restored, all before the poll timeout hits.

So I think the event trigger part of this change is mostly right, except that we need to trigger the event from ZooKeeperClient._connectionListener, and we probably need to double check the event right after the poll call below.
Ack. I used the event based approach as I wanted to avoid races in case the connection is lost but the client reconnects immediately.

deploy-guide/source/features/public-tls..message:
This section is duplicated with the introduction in tls-everywhere.rst.

We could consolidate them but we have to keep it as a separate document in the guide.
This isn't needed for public tls.

This is an extremely slimmed down version of the existing public TLS documentation.

The current documentation goes into detail about all the different ways you can provide certificates, who signs them, and whatnot.

My goal with the initial version of this document is to assume something that would be used in the real world, so:

* certificates issued from a trusted third-party
* FQDNs are used in the overcloud

There are a multitude of other ways we can configured public TLS (with or without DNS and either self-signing the certificates or not).

Since it's not recommended to self-sign certificates, I'm targetting what I think would be most useful for a user deploying OpenStack via TripleO for production (proper domain names and certificates issued from a third-party).

The other cases are certainly useful for development or test deployments. I'm thinking about adding those steps as separate sections of this guide so that readers can clearly distinguish what they do and don't need to deploy public TLS for their use case.

Thoughts?
"comes at the expense of leaving internal network traffic unencrypted. For attackers who gain access to this network, it will take very little effort to compromise additional infrastructure."

++

I used slightly different wording regarding network plurality since internal traffic is everything but the public network.

Let me know if this is more clear.

Should we mention something about where those certs would come from and the kinds of things that should be in the cert?

Maybe we don't need to detail them here - but we could point back to the relevant section in Oz's original doc?

I'm ok with only detailing here the DNS case from an external CA, but we should specify that this is what we are detailing - and refer back for other options.

Can you elaborate a little more on the example you're looking for, specifically the bit about certificate contents?

Are you looking for an example that generates a certificate?

It is very likely that the CA cert they have may not come from a CA in the trusted store.  Therefore we should mention the  ../environments/ssl/inject-trust-anchor.yaml file and what needs to go in there.  And the caMap.

Can we please move forward with this PR? its hanging for long time. My other PR in ipa-builder is cannot be merged because of this PR. Could you please help?

Without the --force-resolution the build was failing. The logs during the run_zypper dist-upgrade says, upgrade was unable to proceed because there were few options available and without resolution, it cannot decide which options it would follow. So by adding --force-resolution, it would choose the default upgrade option. So this helps the upgrade process to move forward and build was successfull.

this globally changes things from only matching on suse to matching on every platform with /etc/os-release.  should this be behind some other sort of check?

I don't know the answer, but I'd like to see it justified why it's correct to change it like this.

What I mean is that this match used to exclusively match on suse systems, and now it seems to match on pretty much all systems.  I'm pretty sure gentoo (below this) has /etc/os-release so this seems to effectively shortcut/break this?

I'm pretty sure this needs to limit itself to suse, or otherwise explain why this is right
If I change the condition to ""elif [ $IPA_DISTRO_FAMILY = "suse" ]; then"", does it solve your concern..

if [[ $DISTRO_NAME = opensuse ]]

I have tried locally with  $DISTRO_FAMILY = "opensuse" and  $IPA_DISTRO_FAMILY = "suse" . Both of them are failing. You have said earlier in your comment about gentoo and it has os-release. Here it seems that gentoo has /etc/gentoo.release. Which doesn't work for openSuse. only etc/os-release is supported by suse based distro.

/etc/SuSE-release was already deprecated from openSuse 13 version and with new distribution it is renamed to /os-release for openSuse. As this change only necessary for openSuse, I don't think it needs some other checks. Locally my test was passing for openSuse.

I don't think that's right.  os-release is FHS standard [1]; most distros will have this file.

cinder/api/contrib/backups.py.message: isn't this class used by both v2 and v3?  And resource_filters is only a v3 thing.  I think using the resource filters is handled by the decorator.

I did this change to make all API's consistent and there are a few things i considered before making this change:
1) V3 backup code calls the index/detail here which in turn calls this method for filtering
2) get_enabled_resource_filters was introduced in Pike (before which we will never backport this change) and it doesn't do any microversion check, so it's safe to assume this will never throw an error
3) This causes a limitation for the V3 backup API that the filters are hardcoded and not configurable by admin in resource_filters.json file
4) Similar change is done for v2 volumes API[1] (although I'm not sure it's entirely correct and if that relates with my intention here)

But thinking about this again, maybe it will make more sense when we remove the V2 API, move methods to V3 only and then introduce this change. Let me know your thoughts.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/commit/ee1ac541253c42e3d94c907cb5b49a1172d68817

I really don't know why i made this change since i realized that code never reaches this patch if we specify MV>=3.31
you're correct the decorator handles the general filtering and this method is only executed if MV<=3.31
The functionality behaves correctly with resource_filters.json file for backups so please ignore my previous comment.

What bothers me about this issue is that we don't understand why this is now happening where this used to work.

So if we aren't going to address the root cause, I would prefer a fix that is only executed when the problem occurs.

From my experimentation, once this failure occurs, the next subsequent helm->tiller->postgres action will re-establish the connection and work correctly. 

I think we should implement a retry here on the exception so we aren't always resetting tiller.

  import retrying
  def _retry_on_HelmTillerFailure(ex):  # pylint: disable=no-self-argument
      LOG.info('Caught HelmTillerFailure exception. Retrying... '
               'Exception: {}'.format(ex))
      return isinstance(ex, exception.HelmTillerFailure)

  @retrying.retry(stop_max_attempt_number=2,
                  retry_on_exception=_retry_on_HelmTillerFailure)
  def get_openstack_pending_install_charts():

I think the above should do the trick. Then when the root cause of the disconnection is discovered and fixed we are left code that will never retry and "just work" again.

You dont need this disable here.
The other places we call retrying are within classes, which is why we have had to do this there, but since this is a utility method, that disable is not needed.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Compatibility to what? Wallaby? Xena? Was this intended for the wallaby release? Was the 6.0.0 release not actually a breaking change? Is semver just not being followed? We really need to understand the details to be able to review a patch.

I updated the commit message to clarify it is compatibility of Wallaby. So, yes, it is intended for the Wallaby release.

Release 6.0.0 does not contain a breaking change. While semver is being followed, all backward compatible changes are backported to stable branches, both bug fixes and new features.

To avoid release number namespace collisions, the major version must be incremented for every release. In the past, there was typically a breaking change. However, over the past couple of release cycles, during which there was a markedly reduced amount of change to this package, there have been no breaking changes. Therefore, the major number has been unconditionally incremented.
